Description: Terracotta squatting ithyphallic figure playing double-pipes. A naked man or satyr modelled in the round and seated on a cushion, playing double pipes between which his large phallus rises; his head is lost. He is corpulent, with a roll of flesh creased at his waist behind. The head and the left foot are gone and the rectangular plinth is damaged. Solid; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a grey-brown core and white inclusions. Remains of a white dressing, with pink paint on the flesh areas.
Curator's comments: Very similar to GR1973,0501.29 (Bailey 2008, no. 3234), but not from the same mould. Similar to other Late Period to early Ptolemaic Harpocrates pieces found at Naukratis. Bailey, D.M. 2008, Catalogue of Egyptian Terracottas in the British Museum, IV, London.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3235)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.190) (Phase 1)
